  • 2.I.3F

    #Probability
    2001

    The following problem is known as Bertrand's paradox. A chord has been chosen at random in a circle of radius rrr. Find the probability that it is longer than the side of the equilateral triangle inscribed in the circle. Consider three different cases:

    a) the middle point of the chord is distributed uniformly inside the circle,

    b) the two endpoints of the chord are independent and uniformly distributed over the circumference,

    c) the distance between the middle point of the chord and the centre of the circle is uniformly distributed over the interval [0,r][0, r][0,r].

    [Hint: drawing diagrams may help considerably.]

    comment

  • 2.I.4F

    #Probability
    2001

    The Ruritanian authorities decided to pardon and release one out of three remaining inmates, A,BA, BA,B and CCC, kept in strict isolation in the notorious Alkazaf prison. The inmates know this, but can't guess who among them is the lucky one; the waiting is agonising. A sympathetic, but corrupted, prison guard approaches AAA and offers to name, in exchange for a fee, another inmate (not A)A)A) who is doomed to stay. He says: "This reduces your chances to remain here from 2/32 / 32/3 to 1/21 / 21/2 : will it make you feel better?" AAA hesitates but then accepts the offer; the guard names BBB.

    Assume that indeed BBB will not be released. Determine the conditional probability

    P(A remains ∣B named )=P(A&B remain )P(B named )P(A \text { remains } \mid B \text { named })=\frac{P(A \& B \text { remain })}{P(B \text { named })} P(A remains ∣B named )=P(B named )P(A&B remain )​

    and thus check the guard's claim, in three cases:

    a) when the guard is completely unbiased (i.e., names any of BBB and CCC with probability 1/21 / 21/2 if the pair B,CB, CB,C is to remain jailed),

    b) if he hates BBB and would certainly name him if BBB is to remain jailed,

    c) if he hates CCC and would certainly name him if CCC is to remain jailed.

    a) that I win at least one game,

    b) that I win at least two games,

    d) that I win exactly two games in succession (i.e., games 1 and 2 or 2 and 3 , but not 1,2 and 3 ),

    e) that I win exactly two games (i.e., 1 and 2 or 2 and 3 or 1 and 3 , but not 1,2 and 3))).

    Dipkomsky, a desperado in the wild West, is surrounded by an enemy gang and fighting tooth and nail for his survival. He has mmm guns, m>1m>1m>1, pointing in different directions and tries to use them in succession to give an impression that there are several defenders. When he turns to a subsequent gun and discovers that the gun is loaded he fires it with probability 1/21 / 21/2 and moves to the next one. Otherwise, i.e. when the gun is unloaded, he loads it with probability 3/43 / 43/4 or simply moves to the next gun with complementary probability 1/41 / 41/4. If he decides to load the gun he then fires it or not with probability 1/21 / 21/2 and after that moves to the next gun anyway.

    Initially, each gun had been loaded independently with probability ppp. Show that if after each move this distribution is preserved, then p=3/7p=3 / 7p=3/7. Calculate the expected value ENE NEN and variance Var NNN of the number NNN of loaded guns under this distribution.

    [Hint: it may be helpful to represent NNN as a sum ∑1≤j≤mXj\sum_{1 \leq j \leq m} X_{j}∑1≤j≤m​Xj​ of random variables taking values 0 and 1.]

The four roads connecting the villages follow the sides of the rectangle; the distance from WWW to XXX and YYY to ZZZ is 5 miles and from WWW to ZZZ and YYY to X10X 10X10 miles. After delivering a customer the taxi waits until the next call then goes to pick up the new customer and takes him to his destination. The calls may come from any of the villages with probability 1/41 / 41/4 and each customer goes to any other village with probability 1/31 / 31/3. Naturally, when travelling between a pair of adjacent corners of the rectangle, the taxi takes the straight route, otherwise (when it travels from WWW to YYY or XXX to ZZZ or vice versa) it does not matter. Distances within a given village are negligible. Let DDD be the distance travelled to pick up and deliver a single customer. Find the probabilitites that DDD takes each of its possible values. Find the expected value EDE DED and the variance Var DDD.
